1.body: Good point.  The button allows you to rotate the camera but I haven't implemented jump, 180 degree quick turn, or dash/charge. 2.author: sleepingfox307
2.body:
Haha yeah, the classroom environment is *not* for the faint of heart!

I wasn't a teacher exactly, my official title was "behavior tech" I was kind of a cross between a therapist and a para, there to help the kids stay regulated and assist the actual teachers in any way they needed. And also to intervene when shit did, inevitably, hit the fan lol

It was an interesting job.

Good teachers deserve all the respect (and much better pay!)

But yes, "ink therapy" is pretty great

2.author: megmonique
2.body:
I'm still a tat virgin... not that I can't handle pain (I actually have a high threshold), but I still haven't thought of or seen anything I would want on my body forever. Plus, I don't know why this was pounded into my head or by whom, but if you're tattooed, you can't be buried in a Jewish cemetery! Wtf?? I was raised in a strict Southern Baptist household; where did that come from and why is it still in my brain?? No clue.

I admire your artistic abilities as well; something I was never gifted with. I can play almost any musical instrument, but put a pencil in my hand and tell me to draw and you're getting stick figures. 😉

2.author: sleepingfox307
2.body:
Haha they’re not for everyone

And I didn’t know that about Jewish cemeteries, that’s in my brain forever now lol 

I play a few instruments as well! Not nearly like I used to though. Not as much time to practice these days, BUT stick figures can be great, one of my favorite comics (xkcd) is all stick figures

3.author: WeasternMedicine9
3.body:
I agree that most of the time, it's pretty much like going on a farm, shoot a cow and call it hunting. 

Where I grew up, there isn't much deer, a low male to female ratio, and it lives in places where they're almost never in contact with humans. You're only allowed 1 buck per season, and there's a draw for calf/female licenses every year, but they give most of them to 1st year hunters. Most people have salt licks, they feed apples, carrots, and grain months before the season. Even then, a lot of them spend years without tagging one. 

It wasn't my point though, I meant that in some areas, salt licks and feeding is allowed, but live bait is illegal. From early summer to fall, bait, feed and minerals are selling like toilet paper early pandemic. It probably brings in more tax money than deer and fishing licenses

3.author: zahzensoldier
3.body: Yeah, my apologies, I wasn't meaning to attack you or anything like that. I was raised to believe any "hunting" where you don't have to track the deer or you set up bait is like shooting fish in a barrel and it takes all of the gamesmanship out of the hunt. The people who tended to do those things where I live (its illegal) were generally garbage people who didn't care about the ecosystem or the nature they were mucking up so I have an extremely bad reaction to it.

3.author: WeasternMedicine9
3.body:
No offense taken, I'm of the same advice in most cases, I just wanted to explain how it can be different depending on the area and the deer population. I'm sorry if I sounded bitter, English is my second language. Here, only a few older men who spent years walking and hunting the same forest can track deer successfully.

For us, those garbage piece of shit hunters are usually those who don't have access to private land or aren't leasing a lot. They drive around dirt roads with a loaded rifle and an open beer, shooting at first sight no matter where it is, trespassing and braking property. We own land, and we have to push back agressive entitled hunters every year. We catch some poaching, breaking our main gate to trespass, and the list goes on.

3.author: zahzensoldier
3.body:
Nah you're good my guy! I thunk the additional context was great because I would have assumed those practices were the same in most places. It's good to hear about different practices and different justifications for those practices in different areas. 

I appreciate the back and forth.

3.author: WeasternMedicine9
3.body:
I do too, it's always great to discussion with someone who has different opinions when both are open to the other's perspective.

 Wanting to understand should be the goal of any conversation, rather than trying to win by discrediting the other's perspective. Unfortunately, very few seem to apply this concept, not to mention on Reddit. 

 Thanks for making this brief exchange enjoyable by being so courteous and open-minded. Cheers!

I did. That is evidence supporting the claim. You can decide it isn't strong enough to sway your thinking about the reason HC is leaving, and that's fine. But it is sources and they do support the claim.

If you're looking for a source that directly states it from HC or a manager, rather than just be rumor from insider sources that know what's going on... good luck. That shit is in NDAs. They're not going to speak out publicly about it because they could get sued. You'll never be satisfied, lol.

11.author: schlachten_funf
11.body: Lol David was also one time work. What’s your point. And nah, writing Gcode is a lot more complex then the code 3D printers spit out.

11.author: bkdroid
11.body:
There are slicer add-ons that allow for non-planar and multiple extruders. Obviously not to this level, but it is on the path there.

The one-time work is the programming to make a slicer for sculpting. Writing out full GCODE for every project sounds equivalent to doing the sculpting manually every time. Seems like a wasted opportunity for efficiency.

11.author: schlachten_funf
11.body:
Yes of course you’d always have the code to recreate the sculpture…my point is that using cam software to write Gcode (this is not done like a 3D print slicer) is more complex than what your 3D printer does.

EDIT: I’m a cnc machinist

11.author: bkdroid
11.body:
I acknowledge that it's more complicated, but you're not programming every individual movement (I hope). The 5-axis CAM programs let you import the model and develop a basic tool path in a few minutes. 

Of course, something at this level of detail will take a not insubstantial amount of effort to get right, but not the full year +/- that sculpting by hand will. 

​

Source: Watched half of a youtube video on a 5-axis CAM software. (I'm also now an expert in epidemiology, economics, and political science).

11.author: schlachten_funf
11.body: If your debate is “is this easier than sculpting by hand,” the answer is obviously yes. I’m just making the point that the computer here isn’t doing it for you. It’s not making decisions. The Cam software is not making decisions. A lot of work goes into it.

11.author: bkdroid
11.body: Agreed. I think we can meet in the middle. I oversimplified that using software could create a 5 minute masterpiece, and you overexaggerated the 'programming every movement'. Both for effect, rather than explicit process.

And this (sub)genre of music, by its very nature is not trying to be mainstream.  By such a standard contemporary pop music with highly discernible beats is somehow rhythmically better than even the work of the classic rock drummers you listed, an absurd notion.

13.author: zymurgest
13.body: So you're comparing electronic/synthesized to human effort?  Agreed, absurd.

13.author: FrostyBrew86
13.body: I never said electronic music.  Taylor Swift plays live and records with a human drummer, and Meg White... exists.  Modern music is all recorded and played live to a click track, so the music is rhythmically more precise.  If you scrutinize the rhythm of classic rock albums, the timing tends to drift.

22.author: LouisACook
22.body: This appears to be a plaster cast of a frame, making this a fresco. The first layer looks like just underpainting to me.

22.author: Forced_Democracy
22.body: Nah, frescos are painted while the plaster is wet. The images of frescos aren't just on the surface but penetrate deeper into the plaster. If you scratch a fresco, the pigment still shows through.

22.author: LouisACook
22.body: true but How can you tell the plaster is dry? She takes it out of a silicone mold and starts painting almost immediately.

22.author: Forced_Democracy
22.body: Probably from how broken it is and she can pick it up without disturbing the shape and able to glue it down. It may be damp but it seems to bright of a color for that to be so. Also, she put what looks like a primer or base coat of some sorts.

22.author: LouisACook
22.body: Maybe. But plaster fully sets up in like 25 min- way faster than the time it takes to make any oil painting. It stays "wet" for a long time after that. it's not like glue drying, it's a reaction like cement and similarly still has water in it after it's set up. You can break it just fine when it's wet or dry. It would be tough to paint on a plaster ceiling or wall, as most famous frescos are, on goopy unset plaster in less than 30 minutes. Also, oil pigment would still seep into dry plaster just fine- possibly even better without the water sealing it out. It's chalky and porous.

22.author: Forced_Democracy
22.body: I think I might have to agree with you and change my mind. Not entirely convinced but you make some good arguments.

22.author: LouisACook
22.body: i am not totally sure either. but happy to be having a discussion on the internet where everyone is nice :)
